sentences: Jeffrey LeVasseur (born August 27, 1961), known as Jeffrey Steele, is an American country music singer and songwriter.

Between 1990 and 1996, Steele was the lead singer and bass guitarist in the country music band Boy Howdy, which recorded two albums and an EP on Curb Records, in addition to charting seven singles on the Billboard country music charts.
He also charted four singles as a solo artist, with the highest-peaking ("Somethin' in the Water") reaching No. 33 on the country charts in 2001.
In 1987, after the death of his father, LeVasseur changed his last name to Steele as a tribute to his father, who processed steel for a living.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: In 1990, Steele and three other California musicians – Hugh Wright, along with brothers Cary and Larry Park – formed the band Boy Howdy, in which he served as lead vocalist and bass guitarist.
section: == Boy Howdy ==

sentences: Boy Howdy signed to Curb Records in 1992, recording three albums and an EP for the label, in addition to charting seven singles on the country music charts.
section: == Boy Howdy ==

sentences: Steele re-located to Nashville, Tennessee in 1994, two years before Boy Howdy disbanded.
section: == Solo career and success as songwriter ==

sentences: In 1996, he released three solo singles, as well as a self-titled solo album which was never shipped.
section: == Solo career and success as songwriter ==

sentences: In 2001, Steele was signed to his second solo recording contract, this time with Monument Records.
section: == Solo career and success as songwriter ==

sentences: Steele earned his first Number One song with Tim McGraw's "The Cowboy in Me" in 2002.
section: == Solo career and success as songwriter ==

sentences: In addition, Rascal Flatts reached Number One on the country charts in late 2002 with "These Days", their first Number One single.
section: == Solo career and success as songwriter ==

sentences: Steele also continued to record studio albums even while writing hits for other artists; his albums Gold, Platinum, Chrome and Steele and You Gotta Start Somewhere were both released in 2003, the same year that he was named Songwriter of the Year by both BMI and the Nashville Songwriters Association International (NSAI).
section: == Solo career and success as songwriter ==

sentences: 2004 saw the release of his fourth studio album, Outlaw, on the Lofton Creek Records label.
section: == Solo career and success as songwriter ==

sentences: By 2005, more than sixty of his songs had become chart hits for other artists; that same year, he received a second Songwriter of the Year award from the NSAI.
section: == Solo career and success as songwriter ==

sentences: The song was a Number One single on both the Hot Country Songs and Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks charts for Rascal Flatts in 2006, and was also a chart single for Cascada in 2007.

sentences: Another one of Steele's compositions, Steve Holy's Number One single "Brand New Girlfriend", earned him yet another BMI award in 2006, as well as the Rascal Flatts hit "My Wish" just as Steele released his album, Hell on Wheels.
